questions: A 71-year-old patient with a 2-month history of a cough and associated weight loss shows a suspicious lung mass on chest X-ray. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
notes:
NICE recommends that patients with known or suspected lung cancer are offered a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest, liver and adrenals.

MRI is not usually used to assess non-small cell lung cancer.

Biopsy should not be performed before a CT scan.

Non-contrast CT scan is less accurate than contrast CT scan in this setting, and so is not advised.

PET scan should not be offered at this stage.

References:
NICE (2011). Lung cancer: diagnosis and management.
question: A 71-year-old patient with a 2-month history of a cough and associated weight loss shows a suspicious lung mass on chest X-ray. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
question_notes:
NICE recommends that patients with known or suspected lung cancer are offered a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest, liver and adrenals.

MRI is not usually used to assess non-small cell lung cancer.

Biopsy should not be performed before a CT scan.

Non-contrast CT scan is less accurate than contrast CT scan in this setting, and so is not advised.

PET scan should not be offered at this stage.

References:
NICE (2011). Lung cancer: diagnosis and management.
title: Lung cancer: investigation
body:
Chest x-ray
  • still the first-line investigation done in patients with suspected lung cancer who present to primary care
  • in around 10% of patients subsequently diagnosed with lung cancer the chest x-ray was reported as normal


CT
  • is the investigation of choice to investigate suspected lung cancer

Bronchoscopy
  • this allows a biopsy to be taken to obtain a histological diagnosis sometimes aided by endobronchial ultrasound

PET scanning
  • is typically done in non-small cell lung cancer to establish eligibility for curative treatment
  • uses 18-fluorodeoxygenase which is preferentially taken up by neoplastic tissue
  • has been shown to improve diagnostic sensitivity of both local and distant metastasis spread in non-small cell lung cancer

Bloods
  • raised platelets may be seen
links:
Royal College of Physicians36
2012 PET/CT in oncology review


Radiopaedia33
Lung cancer review

Cancers of the lung

Oncology for Medical Students - YouTube00

questions:
A 6-year-old boy is taken to see the GP by his mother. He has been complaining of pain in the left hip for the past 48 hours and his mother noticed him limping while playing with friends. He has no significant past medical history except for a minor viral upper respiratory tract infection one week ago.

On examination, there is no obvious swelling or deformity of the hip. Some movement of the hip is tolerated, but excess motion causes him to complain of pain. His observations are within normal limits.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
This young boy's presentation is most suggestive of transient synovitis, a relatively common condition that usually affects children between the ages of three and eight. It is the most common cause of hip pain in children and typically occurs following a recent viral infection, as seen here. It is characterised by a limp or refusal to weight bear, and groin/hip pain. In the absence of red flag features (such as high fever), it may be monitored in primary care; it is self-limiting.

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis is incorrect. This diagnosis can only be made after 6 weeks of objective arthritis in the joint, including stiffness in the morning or after inactivity.

Legg-Calve-Perthes' disease is incorrect. This condition is more common in boys, although it presents with a much more insidious limp, gradually occurring over weeks to months. The presentation in this scenario is far more acute.

Osgood-Schlatter disease is incorrect. This causes knee pain, rather than hip pain. It is usually localised to the tibial tuberosity and occurs in slightly older children. It is caused by multiple small avulsion fractures.

Slipped upper femoral epiphysis is incorrect. This tends to occur in slightly older children, typically during the adolescent growth spurt, and particularly in children who are overweight. In a child aged 6, transient synovitis is more likely.

Slipped upper femoral epiphysis is incorrect. This tends to occur in slightly older children, typically during the adolescent growth spurt, and particularly in children who are overweight. In a child aged 6, transient synovitis is more likely.
title: Transient synovitis
body:
Transient synovitis is sometimes referred to as irritable hip. It generally presents as acute hip pain following a recent viral infection. It is the commonest cause of hip pain in children. The typical age group is 3-8 years.

Features
  • limp/refusal to weight bear
  • groin or hip pain
  • a low-grade fever is present in a minority of patients
    • high fever should raise the suspicion of other causes such as septic arthritis

NICE help us with the difficult task of excluding septic arthritis and other serious diagnoses in children who present with a limp. They suggest:
  • fever is a red flag, indicating the need for urgent specialist assessment
  • children may be monitored in primary care (with a presumptive diagnosis of transient synovitis) 'If the child is aged 3-9 years, well, afebrile, mobile but limping, and has had the symptoms for less than 72 hours

Transient synovitis is self-limiting, requiring only rest and analgesia.
concept: Transient synovitis is most commonly seen in children aged 3-8 years
media:
Paediatric Limp: Differential Frameworks
Townsend Teaching - YouTube113

2372.concept_text: A child with hip pain, limp and recent infective illness --> ? transient synovitis

2977.concept_text: Transient synovitis is often associated with a mild fever

3026.concept_text: Transient synovitis is most commonly seen in children aged 3-8 years

11508.concept_text: If a child with a limp/hip pain has a fever they should be referred for same-day assessment, even if a diagnosis of transient synovitis is suspected

questions:
A 52-year-old male patient presents to the GP surgery with a 3-year history of progressively worsening hip and back pain. He reports the hip pain is worse on weight-bearing and improves with rest. On examination, you noticed frontal bossing and bowing of the legs.

What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for his condition ?
notes:
This patient has Paget's disease and the first line treatments are bisphosphonates

Vitamin D replacement is not a treatment of the Paget's disease.

Radiotherapy is a treatment for osteosarcoma.

Cinacalcet is used to treat hypercalcaemia secondary to hyperparathyroidism.

Oral phosphate binders are used in renal failure.
question:
A 52-year-old male patient presents to the GP surgery with a 3-year history of progressively worsening hip and back pain. He reports the hip pain is worse on weight-bearing and improves with rest. On examination, you noticed frontal bossing and bowing of the legs.

What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for his condition ?
question_notes:
This patient has Paget's disease and the first line treatments are bisphosphonates

Vitamin D replacement is not a treatment of the Paget's disease.

Radiotherapy is a treatment for osteosarcoma.

Cinacalcet is used to treat hypercalcaemia secondary to hyperparathyroidism.

Oral phosphate binders are used in renal failure.
title: Paget's disease of the bone
body:
Paget's disease is a disease of increased but uncontrolled bone turnover. It is thought to be primarily a disorder of osteoclasts, with excessive osteoclastic resorption followed by increased osteoblastic activity. Paget's disease is common (UK prevalence 5%) but symptomatic in only 1 in 20 patients. The skull, spine/pelvis, and long bones of the lower extremities are most commonly affected.

Predisposing factors
  • increasing age
  • male sex
  • northern latitude
  • family history

Clinical features - only 5% of patients are symptomatic
  • the stereotypical presentation is an older male with bone pain and an isolated raised ALP
  • bone pain (e.g. pelvis, lumbar spine, femur)
  • classical, untreated features: bowing of tibia, bossing of skull

Investigations
  • bloods
    • raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
    • calcium and phosphate are typically normal. Hypercalcaemia may occasionally occur with prolonged immobilisation
  • other markers of bone turnover include
    • procollagen type I N-terminal propeptide (PINP)
    • serum C-telopeptide (CTx)
    • urinary N-telopeptide (NTx)
    • urinary hydroxyproline
  • x-rays
    • plain radiographs are the first-line investigation and are usually diagnostic
    • osteolysis in early disease → mixed lytic/sclerotic lesions later
    • skull x-ray: thickened vault, osteoporosis circumscripta
  • bone scintigraphy
    • increased uptake is seen focally at the sites of active bone lesions

Management
  • indications for treatment include
    • bone pain
    • skull or long bone deformity
    • fracture
    • periarticular Paget's
  • bisphosphonate (either oral risedronate or IV zoledronate)
  • calcitonin is less commonly used now

Complications
  • deafness (cranial nerve entrapment)
  • bone sarcoma (1% if affected for > 10 years)
  • fractures
  • skull thickening
  • high-output cardiac failure
concept: Paget's disease of the bone is treated with bisphosphonates
links:
Radiopaedia.org107
Paget disease (bone)


Journal of Bone and Mineral Research153
2019 Paget's disease of the bone guidelines
media:
Paget's Disease of the bone
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube00
 
Paget's disease of the bone
Osmosis - YouTube111

154.concept_text: Paget's disease - old man, bone pain, raised ALP

3034.concept_text: Paget's disease of the bone is treated with bisphosphonates

5017.concept_text: Paget's disease of the bone generally affects the skull, spine/pelvis, and long bones of the lower extremities

questions:
A 70-year-old man is reviewed. For the past two weeks his family report that he has been generally unwell, 'not himself' and lethargic. His past history includes ischaemic heart disease (myocardial infarction 8 years ago), chronic kidney disease (stage 4) and depression (for which he takes imipramine). Physical examination is unremarkable with no new findings. You obtain an ECG:

© Image used on license from Dr Smith, University of Minnesota

Which one of the following is most likely to explain the changes seen on the ECG?
notes: The standout feature of this ECG is the tall 'tented' T waves in the anterior leads. This finding is associated with hyperkalaemia.
question:
A 70-year-old man is reviewed. For the past two weeks his family report that he has been generally unwell, 'not himself' and lethargic. His past history includes ischaemic heart disease (myocardial infarction 8 years ago), chronic kidney disease (stage 4) and depression (for which he takes imipramine). Physical examination is unremarkable with no new findings. You obtain an ECG:

© Image used on license from Dr Smith, University of Minnesota

Which one of the following is most likely to explain the changes seen on the ECG?
question_notes: The standout feature of this ECG is the tall 'tented' T waves in the anterior leads. This finding is associated with hyperkalaemia.
title: Hyperkalaemia
body:
Plasma potassium levels are regulated by a number of factors including aldosterone, acid-base balance and insulin levels. Metabolic acidosis is associated with hyperkalaemia as hydrogen and potassium ions compete with each other for exchange with sodium ions across cell membranes and in the distal tubule. ECG changes seen in hyperkalaemia include tall-tented T waves, small P waves, widened QRS leading to a sinusoidal pattern and asystole

Causes of hyperkalaemia:
  • acute kidney injury
  • drugs*: potassium sparing diuretics, ACE inhibitors, angiotensin 2 receptor blockers, spironolactone, ciclosporin, heparin**
  • metabolic acidosis
  • Addison's disease
  • rhabdomyolysis
  • massive blood transfusion

Foods that are high in potassium:
  • salt substitutes (i.e. Contain potassium rather than sodium)
  • bananas, oranges, kiwi fruit, avocado, spinach, tomatoes

*beta-blockers interfere with potassium transport into cells and can potentially cause hyperkalaemia in renal failure patients - remember beta-agonists, e.g. Salbutamol, are sometimes used as emergency treatment

**both unfractionated and low-molecular weight heparin can cause hyperkalaemia. This is thought to be caused by inhibition of aldosterone secretion
links:
National Kidney Foundation169
Renal Diet
media:
Understanding Hyperkalaemia (High Potassium)
Zero To Finals - YouTube50
 
Hyperkalemia
Osmosis - YouTube41

questions:
A 75-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with new onset lethargy, nausea and visual disturbances. She has a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin for rate control. Her heart rate is 85 bpm, and an ECG shows ST-segment depression and T-wave flattening.

Blood tests show the following:

Serum digoxin level2.8 ng/mL(0.8-2.0)

What is the most likely precipitant of this clinical picture?
notes:
Bendroflumethiazide is the correct answer. Bendroflumethiazide is a thiazide diuretic that causes potassium loss, leading to hypokalaemia. Hypokalaemia makes the heart more sensitive to the effects of digoxin, exacerbating its toxic effects. Digoxin toxicity can cause ECG changes such as ST-segment depression and T-wave flattening, along with symptoms such as nausea, dizziness, lethargy, and vision changes, as described in the scenario. Blood tests confirm that digoxin concentration is raised, although digoxin toxicity can even occur when the concentration is within the therapeutic range.

Bisoprolol is a beta-blocker and does not directly impact potassium levels or digoxin clearance. However, both digoxin and bisoprolol can increase the risk of bradycardia.

Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic, which tends to increase potassium levels rather than lower them, which is protective against digoxin toxicity. The BNF states that it very slightly increases the exposure to digoxin. However, it is much less likely than bendroflumethiazide to cause digoxin toxicity, and the BNF states this as a mild caution.

Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor, which can increase potassium rather than lower it, reducing the risk of digoxin toxicity.

St John's wort is a herbal supplement known to reduce the effectiveness of many drugs by inducing cytochrome P450 liver enzymes. It would more likely decrease digoxin levels rather than increase them, making it an unlikely precipitant of digoxin toxicity.

Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor, which can increase potassium rather than lower it, reducing the risk of digoxin toxicity.

St John's wort is a herbal supplement known to reduce the effectiveness of many drugs by inducing cytochrome P450 liver enzymes. It would more likely decrease digoxin levels rather than increase them, making it an unlikely precipitant of digoxin toxicity.
title: Digoxin and digoxin toxicity
body:
Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside now mainly used for rate control in the management of atrial fibrillation. As it has positive inotropic properties it is sometimes used for improving symptoms (but not mortality) in patients with heart failure.

Mechanism of action
  • decreases conduction through the atrioventricular node which slows the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation and flutter
  • increases the force of cardiac muscle contraction due to inhibition of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. Also stimulates vagus nerve
  • digoxin has a narrow therapeutic index

Monitoring
  • digoxin level is not monitored routinely, except in suspected toxicity
  • if toxicity is suspected, digoxin concentrations should be measured within 8 to 12 hours of the last dose


Digoxin toxicity

Plasma concentration alone does not determine whether a patient has developed digoxin toxicity. Toxicity may occur even when the concentration is within the therapeutic range. The BNF advises that the likelihood of toxicity increases progressively from 1.5 to 3 mcg/l.

Features
  • generally unwell, lethargy, nausea & vomiting, anorexia, confusion, yellow-green vision
  • arrhythmias (e.g. AV block, bradycardia)
  • gynaecomastia

Precipitating factors
  • classically: hypokalaemia
    • digoxin normally binds to the ATPase pump on the same site as potassium. Hypokalaemia → digoxin more easily bind to the ATPase pump → increased inhibitory effects
  • increasing age
  • renal failure
  • myocardial ischaemia
  • hypomagnesaemia, hypercalcaemia, hypernatraemia, acidosis
  • hypoalbuminaemia
  • hypothermia
  • hypothyroidism
  • drugs: amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, spironolactone (competes for secretion in distal convoluted tubule therefore reduce excretion), ciclosporin. Also drugs which cause hypokalaemia e.g. thiazides and loop diuretics


Management
  • Digibind
  • correct arrhythmias
  • monitor potassium
concept: Thiazides may cause precipitation of digoxin toxicity
media:
Digoxin Mnemonic - Cardiac Glycosides (Inotropes)
Medicosis Perfectionalis - YouTube103

515.concept_text: Digoxin - inhibits the Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> ATPase pump

1975.concept_text: Gynaecomastia is a recognised side effect of digoxin

3487.concept_text: Hypokalaemia predisposes patients to digoxin toxicity

3589.concept_text: Type 1 diabetes often presents with the triad of weight loss, polyuria and polydipsia

6689.concept_text: Amiodarone may cause precipitation of digoxin toxicity - if starting amiodarone on a patient taking digoxin the dose should be reduced

6690.concept_text: Verapamil may cause precipitation of digoxin toxicity

6691.concept_text: Diltiazem may cause precipitation of digoxin toxicity

6693.concept_text: Thiazides may cause precipitation of digoxin toxicity

6694.concept_text: Loop diuretics may cause precipitation of digoxin toxicity

6695.concept_text: Ciclosporin may cause precipitation of digoxin toxicity

9713.concept_text: Digoxin level is not monitored routinely, except in suspected toxicity

9763.concept_text: Digoxin toxicity may occur even when the concentration is within the therapeutic range

options: Prescribe regular codeine and review in 1 week
Dip urine and prescribe oral antibiotics if positive
questions: Tom is an 8-year-old boy with known sickle cell disease who presents with very mild pain in his lower back for 2 days. His observations include a blood pressure of 95/60 mmHg, heart rate of 108 bpm, respiratory rate of 32/min and a temperature of 38.1 degrees centigrade. The examination is normal and there is no obvious source of infection. He is in mild pain and is already taking regular paracetamol and ibuprofen. What would be the correct management?
notes:
The correct answer is Admit urgently. In a child with sickle cell disease presenting with fever (temperature >38°C), urgent hospital admission is mandatory regardless of how well they appear. This is because these patients are functionally asplenic and are at high risk of overwhelming sepsis, particularly from encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae. The presence of pain, even if mild, could indicate an early vaso-occlusive crisis. The tachycardia and tachypnoea also suggest systemic involvement. These patients require immediate assessment, blood cultures, and intravenous antibiotics as per national guidelines.

Urgent bloods and review tomorrow is incorrect because waiting until tomorrow could be dangerous given the risk of rapid deterioration in febrile sickle cell patients. These patients require immediate intervention, not delayed assessment.

Prescribe regular codeine and review in 1 week is incorrect for two reasons. Firstly, it fails to address the fever, which is the most concerning feature. Secondly, codeine is not recommended in children due to variable metabolism and risk of respiratory depression.

Prescribe Oramorph and review tomorrow is incorrect because while pain management is important, the fever requires immediate attention and hospital admission. Additionally, reviewing tomorrow is too late given the risk of sepsis.

Dip urine and prescribe oral antibiotics if positive is incorrect because even if a urinary tract infection is identified, oral antibiotics would be insufficient treatment in a febrile sickle cell patient. These patients require intravenous antibiotics and close monitoring due to their immunocompromised status.

Dip urine and prescribe oral antibiotics if positive is incorrect because even if a urinary tract infection is identified, oral antibiotics would be insufficient treatment in a febrile sickle cell patient. These patients require intravenous antibiotics and close monitoring due to their immunocompromised status.
title: Sickle-cell crises: management
body:
General management
  • analgesia e.g. opiates
  • rehydrate
  • oxygen
  • consider antibiotics if evidence of infection
  • blood transfusion
    • indications include: severe or symptomatic anaemia, pregnancy, pre-operative
    • do not rapidly reduce the percentage of Hb S containing cells
  • exchange transfusion
    • indications include: acute vaso-occlusive crisis (stroke, acute chest syndrome, multiorgan failure, splenic sequestration crisis
    • rapidly reduce the percentage of Hb S containing cells
links:
NICE56
2012 Sickle cell disease: managing acute painful episodes in hospital
media:
Sickle cell anaemia
Osmosis - YouTube73

4065.concept_text: Exchange transfusions are a way of reducing the number of sickle red cells and increasing the number of normal red cells, in order to improve oxygenation

4199.concept_text: The main components for managing sickle cell crisis should be analgesia, oxygen, and IV fluids. You can also consider antibiotics if you suspect an infection, and transfusion if the Hb is low

options: Move the patient to the paediatric ward
Perform full ear nose and throat examination
questions:
You are the paediatric SHO on call. You are asked to attend the emergency department to assess a 2-year-old with stridor. When you attend you find the patient sat on his mothers knee leaning forward and drooling. There is audible stridor from the end of the bed. The brief history you obtain reveals the patient has not engaged with the childhood vaccination programme.

Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
notes: This patient is displaying signs of acute epiglottitis. You should not perform invasive examinations including ear nose and throat examinations without a secure airway as this may lead distress and further occlusion of the airway. Basic observations including respiratory rate /min and oxygen saturations may be appropriate if this does not lead to distress however intravenous cannulation is likely to distress the child. The senior paediatric team should be called as should an anaesthetist.
question:
You are the paediatric SHO on call. You are asked to attend the emergency department to assess a 2-year-old with stridor. When you attend you find the patient sat on his mothers knee leaning forward and drooling. There is audible stridor from the end of the bed. The brief history you obtain reveals the patient has not engaged with the childhood vaccination programme.

Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
question_notes: This patient is displaying signs of acute epiglottitis. You should not perform invasive examinations including ear nose and throat examinations without a secure airway as this may lead distress and further occlusion of the airway. Basic observations including respiratory rate /min and oxygen saturations may be appropriate if this does not lead to distress however intravenous cannulation is likely to distress the child. The senior paediatric team should be called as should an anaesthetist.
title: Stridor in children
body:
Causes of stridor in children include:

CauseNotes
CroupCroup is a form of upper respiratory tract infection seen in infants and toddlers. It is characterised by stridor which is caused by a combination of laryngeal oedema and secretions. Parainfluenza viruses account for the majority of cases.

Epidemiology
  • peak incidence at 6 months - 3 years
  • more common in autumn

Features
  • stridor
  • barking cough (worse at night)
  • fever
  • coryzal symptoms
Acute epiglottitis Acute epiglottitis is rare but serious infection caused by Haemophilus influenzae type B. Prompt recognition and treatment is essential as airway obstruction may develop. Epiglottitis generally occurs in children between the ages of 2 and 6 years. The incidence of epiglottitis has decreased since the introduction of the Hib vaccine

Features
  • rapid onset
  • unwell, toxic child
  • stridor
  • drooling of saliva
Inhaled foreign bodySymptoms depend on the site of impaction

Features are of sudden onset
  • coughing
  • choking
  • vomiting
  • stridor
LaryngomalaciaCongenital abnormality of the larynx.

Infants typical present at 4 weeks of age with:
  • stridor
concept: You should not attempt to perform an oral or throat examination a child with suspected acute epiglottitis

questions: A 75-year-old man presents with back pain that comes on when he walks. After taking a full history and completing a neurological and vascular examination which is normal a diagnosis of spinal stenosis is suspected. After prescribing analgesia, what is the most appropriate next step?
notes:
The correct answer is Refer for MRI. In a patient with suspected spinal stenosis, an MRI scan is the most appropriate next step. This is because it can provide detailed images of the spinal cord and surrounding structures, allowing for a clear visualisation of any narrowing (stenosis) that may be present. According to the UK's National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE), MRI is recommended as the first-line imaging modality in patients with suspected lumbar spinal stenosis.

Discussing each of the incorrect answers:

Lumbar spine x-ray: While this can show changes related to aging or injury, it does not provide a detailed image of soft tissues such as intervertebral discs or nerves. Therefore, it would not be sufficient in identifying spinal stenosis.

Arrange physiotherapy: Physiotherapy can indeed be beneficial in managing symptoms associated with spinal stenosis such as pain and mobility issues. However, before starting treatment, confirmation of the diagnosis via appropriate imaging (MRI) is important.

Refer for duplex scan: Duplex scanning combines traditional ultrasound with Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow in vessels. It would be useful if there was suspicion of vascular disease causing claudication symptoms mimicking spinal stenosis but given that vascular examination was normal, this option would not be relevant in this case.

Perform a myeloma screen: Myeloma screening involves blood tests to detect abnormal proteins produced by malignant plasma cells. While back pain could indeed be a symptom of multiple myeloma, there are no other accompanying signs or symptoms suggestive of this condition presented in this scenario such as anaemia or renal impairment. Hence, performing a myeloma screen wouldn't be necessary at this point without additional supporting evidence.
question: A 75-year-old man presents with back pain that comes on when he walks. After taking a full history and completing a neurological and vascular examination which is normal a diagnosis of spinal stenosis is suspected. After prescribing analgesia, what is the most appropriate next step?
question_notes:
The correct answer is Refer for MRI. In a patient with suspected spinal stenosis, an MRI scan is the most appropriate next step. This is because it can provide detailed images of the spinal cord and surrounding structures, allowing for a clear visualisation of any narrowing (stenosis) that may be present. Lumbar spine x-ray: While this can show changes related to aging or injury, it does not provide a detailed image of soft tissues such as intervertebral discs or nerves. Therefore, it would not be sufficient in identifying spinal stenosis.

Arrange physiotherapy: Physiotherapy can indeed be beneficial in managing symptoms associated with spinal stenosis such as pain and mobility issues. However, before starting treatment, confirmation of the diagnosis via appropriate imaging (MRI) is important.

Refer for duplex scan: Duplex scanning combines traditional ultrasound with Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow in vessels. It would be useful if there was suspicion of vascular disease causing claudication symptoms mimicking spinal stenosis but given that vascular examination was normal, this option would not be relevant in this case.

Perform a myeloma screen: Myeloma screening involves blood tests to detect abnormal proteins produced by malignant plasma cells. While back pain could indeed be a symptom of multiple myeloma, there are no other accompanying signs or symptoms suggestive of this condition presented in this scenario such as anaemia or renal impairment. Hence, performing a myeloma screen wouldn't be necessary at this point without additional supporting evidence.
title: Lower back pain
body:
Lower back pain (LBP) is one of the most common presentations seen in practice. Whilst the majority of presentations will be of a non-specific muscular nature it is worth keeping in mind possible causes which may need specific treatment.

Red flags for lower back pain
  • age < 20 years or > 50 years
  • history of previous malignancy
  • night pain
  • history of trauma
  • systemically unwell e.g. weight loss, fever

The table below indicates some specific causes of LBP:

Facet jointMay be acute or chronic
Pain worse in the morning and on standing
On examination there may be pain over the facets. The pain is typically worse on extension of the back
Spinal stenosisUsually gradual onset
Unilateral or bilateral leg pain (with or without back pain), numbness, and weakness which is worse on walking. Resolves when sits down. Pain may be described as 'aching', 'crawling'.
Relieved by sitting down, leaning forwards and crouching down
Clinical examination is often normal
Requires MRI to confirm diagnosis
Ankylosing spondylitisTypically a young man who presents with lower back pain and stiffness
Stiffness is usually worse in morning and improves with activity
Peripheral arthritis (25%, more common if female)
Peripheral arterial diseasePain on walking, relieved by rest
Absent or weak foot pulses and other signs of limb ischaemia
Past history may include smoking and other vascular diseases
links:
NICE1410
2016 Low back pain guidelines

questions: A 19-year-old woman at ten weeks gestation presents to her general practitioner with intermittent vaginal bleeding over the previous month and hyperemesis. Obstetric examination reveals a non-tender, large-for-dates uterus. These symptoms are strongly suggestive of which condition?
notes:
Although placental abruption, placenta praevia and ectopic pregnancy can cause vaginal bleeding they do not present with a non-tender, large-for-dates uterus. Gestational diabetes is not associated with vaginal bleeding or hyperemesis.

Molar pregnancy is a form of gestational trophoblastic disease. In a normal pregnancy, half of the chromosomes come from the father and half come from the mother. Molar pregnancies may be partial or complete. A complete hydatidiform mole has a 46 XX or 46 XY karyotype with all of the genetic material deriving from the father. This is most commonly due to abnormal fertilisation of an empty ovum. A partial hydatidiform mole has a karyotype of 69 XXX or 69 XXY and contains both maternal and paternal chromosomes. Neither pregnancy can produce a viable fetus.

The most common presenting symptom of a molar pregnancy is vaginal bleeding, which may be light or heavy. Uterine size may be large-for-dates in around one quarter of complete molar pregnancies. Complete hydatidiform moles contain large amounts of abnormal chorionic villi, which produce high volumes of beta hCG. This can lead to sequelae such as hyperemesis, hyperthyroidism and other symptoms. Women aged under 20 years and over 35 years are at higher risk of having a molar pregnancy.

Neither pregnancy can produce a viable fetus.

This can lead to sequelae such as hyperemesis, hyperthyroidism and other symptoms. Women aged under 20 years and over 35 years are at higher risk of having a molar pregnancy.
title: Gestational trophoblastic disorders
body:
Describes a spectrum of disorders originating from the placental trophoblast:
  • complete hydatidiform mole
  • partial hydatidiform mole
  • choriocarcinoma

Complete hydatidiform mole

Benign tumour of trophoblastic material. Occurs when an empty egg is fertilized by a single sperm that then duplicates its own DNA, hence the all 46 chromosomes are of paternal origin

Features
  • bleeding in first or early second trimester
  • exaggerated symptoms of pregnancy e.g. hyperemesis
  • uterus large for dates
  • very high serum levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  • hypertension and hyperthyroidism* may be seen

Management
  • urgent referral to specialist centre - evacuation of the uterus is performed
  • effective contraception is recommended to avoid pregnancy in the next 12 months

Around 2-3% go on to develop choriocarcinoma

In a partial mole a normal haploid egg may be fertilized by two sperms, or by one sperm with duplication of the paternal chromosomes. Therefore the DNA is both maternal and paternal in origin. Usually triploid - e.g. 69 XXX or 69 XXY. Fetal parts may be seen

*hCG can mimic thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
links:
RCOG81
2010 Management of gestational trophoblastic disease

questions: A 47-year-old female is reviewed in the neurology clinic. She was diagnosed with epilepsy whilst a teenager and her seizures are well controlled. She is however concerned about increasing numbness of her fingers and soles of her feet. Which one of the following medications is most likely to be responsible?
notes:
The correct answer is Phenytoin. Phenytoin, an antiepileptic drug, can cause peripheral neuropathy, a condition that results in numbness and tingling in the extremities. This side effect is more common with chronic use and high doses of phenytoin. It's important to note that this symptom could also be due to other causes such as diabetes or vitamin B12 deficiency and therefore should be evaluated further.

Lamotrigine is not typically associated with peripheral neuropathy. Instead, it's more commonly linked with skin reactions (including potentially serious ones like Stevens-Johnson syndrome), dizziness, ataxia, and blurred vision.

Sodium valproate, while a common treatment for epilepsy, does not typically cause peripheral neuropathy either. Its main side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances (nausea, vomiting), tremor, weight gain and hair loss. In rare cases, it can cause serious conditions like liver toxicity and pancreatitis.

Ethosuximide is generally used for absence seizures rather than generalized seizures. The most common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances (nausea, vomiting), lethargy or fatigue but not peripheral neuropathy.

Finally, Levetiracetam can cause psychiatric symptoms including mood swings and aggression as well as somnolence but it doesn't usually lead to peripheral neuropathy.

title: Phenytoin
body:
Phenytoin is used in the management of seizures.

Mechanism of action
  • binds to sodium channels increasing their refractory period

Adverse effects

Phenytoin is associated with a large number of adverse effects. These may be divided into acute, chronic, idiosyncratic and teratogenic. Phenytoin is also an inducer of the P450 system.

Acute
  • initially: dizziness, diplopia, nystagmus, slurred speech, ataxia
  • later: confusion, seizures

Chronic
  • common: gingival hyperplasia (secondary to increased expression of platelet derived growth factor, PDGF), hirsutism, coarsening of facial features, drowsiness
  • megaloblastic anaemia (secondary to altered folate metabolism)
  • peripheral neuropathy
  • enhanced vitamin D metabolism causing osteomalacia
  • lymphadenopathy
  • dyskinesia

Idiosyncratic
  • fever
  • rashes, including severe reactions such as toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • hepatitis
  • Dupuytren's contracture*
  • aplastic anaemia
  • drug-induced lupus

Teratogenic
  • associated with cleft palate and congenital heart disease

Monitoring

Phenytoin levels do not need to be monitored routinely but trough levels, immediately before dose should be checked if:
  • adjustment of phenytoin dose
  • suspected toxicity
  • detection of non-adherence to the prescribed medication

*although not listed in the BNF
links:
BNF217
Phenytoin

5034.concept_text: Phenytoin is a P450 enzyme inducer

6333.concept_text: Phenytoin may cause coarsening of facial features

6338.concept_text: Phenytoin may cause toxic epidermal necrolysis
